[Embedding property] Embedding property of [MATH_24] -holomorphic curves in Calabi-Yau manifolds for generic [MATH_25] Yong-Geun Oh Department of Mathematics, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706 \& Korea Institute for Advanced Study, Seoul, Korea oh@math.wisc.edu The senior author is partially supported by the NSF grant \#DMS 0503954
Ke Zhu Department of Mathematics, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, 53706 \& Department of Mathematics, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong kzhu@math.cuhk.edu.hk

abstract In this paper, we prove that for a generic choice of tame (or compatible) almost complex structures [MATH_26] on a symplectic manifold [MATH_27] with [MATH_28] and with its first Chern class [MATH_29] , all somewhere injective [MATH_30] -holomorphic maps from any closed smooth Riemann surface into [MATH_31] are embedded . We derive this result as a consequence of the general optimal 1-jet evaluation transversality result of [MATH_32] -holomorphic maps in general symplectic manifolds that we also prove in this paper. abstract
1-jet evaluation transversality, somewhere injective, embedded [MATH_33] -holomorphic curves, Calabi-Yau manifolds Revision ; Jan 31, 2009

Let [MATH_34] be a symplectic manifold of real dimension [MATH_35] . We denote by [MATH_36] an almost complex structure tame to [MATH_37] and by [MATH_38] the set of tame almost complex structures. It is a classical fact gromov , mcduff that for a generic choice of [MATH_39] , any somewhere injective [MATH_40] -holomorphic curve is a smooth point in the moduli space of [MATH_41] -holomorphic curves : A [MATH_42] -holomorphic curve [MATH_43] is called somewhere injective if there is a point [MATH_44] such that [MATH_45] This fact has been a fundamental point in the definition of Gromov-Witten invariants and the counting problem of [MATH_46] -holomorphic curves. Recent development in the Gromov-Witten theory unravels necessity of finer structure theorem on the image of [MATH_47] -holomorphic curves. In particular a conjectural mathematical definition of Gopakuma-Vafa invariant of BPS-count is closely related to the number of embedded [MATH_48] -holomorphic curves in Calabi-Yau three-folds for a generic choice of [MATH_49] konts , pandh .
Now description of the main results of this paper is in order.

In this paper, we prove the following theorem.

Then there exists a subset [MATH_70] of second category such that for [MATH_71] , for any complex structure [MATH_72] on [MATH_73] , all somewhere injective [MATH_74] -holomorphic maps [MATH_75] are Fredholm regular and embedded whenever [MATH_76] . thm

In fact, we prove the following general theorem which immediately gives rise to Theorem thm:embedded . We prove this theorem by establishing a transversality result for the 1-jet evaluation map (see Proposition trans-Upsilon ) and then by a dimension counting argument.

thm thm:main Let [MATH_82] be any symplectic manifold and [MATH_83] . thm thm:stablemap Suppose [MATH_106] and [MATH_107] . Then there exists a subset [MATH_108] of second category such that for [MATH_109] any stable [MATH_110] -holomorphic map in Calabi-Yau threefolds is one of the following three types : enumerate it is either smooth and embedded or it has smooth domain and factors through the composition [MATH_111] for some embedding [MATH_112] and a ramified covering [MATH_113] or it is a stable map of the type such that all of its irreducible components have the same locus of images as [MATH_114] , an embedded [MATH_115] -holomorphic curve in [MATH_116] , and are ramified over the domain of [MATH_117] , except those of constant components. enumerate The latter two cases can occur only when [MATH_118] is of the form [MATH_119] for some positive integer [MATH_120] and homology class [MATH_121] . thm
A brief outline of this paper is in order.

In section 2, we establish the generic immersion property of [MATH_122] -holomorphic curves (Theorem thm:immersion ) and prove the first half of Theorem thm:main . This section is the most novel and essential part of this paper which involves the 1-jet evaluation of the map [MATH_123] . Consideration of the 1-jet evaluation map in turn forces us to work with the Fredholm setting of [MATH_124] for [MATH_125] so that the 1-jet evaluation map becomes differentiable with respect to the variation of evaluation points, which involves taking two derivatives of the map. With this choice of Sobolev spaces however, the actual Fredholm analysis involving the one-jet evaluation map is rather delicate partly because one has to overcome the fact that the evaluation of an [MATH_126] -map is not defined pointwise. One novelty of our proof is a judicious usage of the structure theorem of distributions with point supports. See the proof of Lemma lem:eta=0 .

The scheme of our proof is motivated by a similar theorem of the authors in oh-zhu which sketched the proof of immersion property of nodal Floer trajectory curves. The latter is in turn partly motivated by Hutchings and Taubes' proof of Theorem 4.1 hutch-taubes which concerns the immersion property of the case of [MATH_127] dimension in a different context : More specifically see the proof of Lemma 4.2 hutch-taubes . There is also a Corollary 3.17 in wendl which also concerns immersion property of somewhere injective [MATH_128] -holomorphic curves for the moduli spaces of dimension [MATH_129] and [MATH_130] . In their proofs, both papers utilize the fact that they concern a low dimensional moduli space of [MATH_131] -holomorphic curves. One comparison between Theorem thm:main and Corollary 3.17 wendl (with the case [MATH_132] ) is that the condition in our theorem is optimal and corresponds to [MATH_133] (for [MATH_134] ) while Wendl's would correspond to [MATH_135] It is, however, conceivable that their proofs, with some modifications, could be generalized to higher dimensional moduli spaces, which we did not check.

Aside from establishing the immersion property, our natural Fredholm framework for the proof of 1-jet evaluation transversality used in section sec:immersion and appendix has its own merit and suits well for the generalization to the study of higher jet evaluation transversality. We hope to come back to the study of this higher order transversality elsewhere.
In section 3, we establish generic one-one property and prove the second half of Theorem thm:main . Theorem thm:embedded stated above then follows by a dimension counting argument.
In section 4, we prove some key lemma, a type of removable singularity theorem for which we utilize a structure theorem of distributions with point supports (see gelfand for example).
In section 5, we discuss some implication of our results to the Gromov-Witten theory of Calabi-Yau threefolds and derive Theorem thm:stablemap .

The senior author would like to thank Pandharipande for his interest on the current work and for some useful discussion on BPS counts. We like to thank an anonymous referee for pointing out some inaccuracies in our Fredholm setting of the previous version of the paper, providing useful suggestions on improvement and pointing out the reference wendl .

In this subsection, we will give the proof of immersion property. This is the most novel and essential part of the present work. Except the proof of this immersion property, the arguments used in other parts are all standard and well-known in the study of pseudo-holomorphic curves.
